concept.title: Specialization

conbody.p: Content moved from the overly-long and over-loaded "Introduction to DITA" topic.Specialization permits the creation of new DITA elements that address the specific requirements of a business or industry, while still sharing the common output transformations and design rules that were developed for the more general types and domains. This is similar to how classes in an object-oriented system inherit the methods of ancestor classes. The implementation of specialization-specific processing is generally done through the extension of existing processing rather than through complete re-implementation of all required processing. DITA's specialization architecture is similar to object-oriented systems where specialized types can inherit the semantics and, by implication, the processing of their base types.

DITA imposes a set of constraints on extension that ensures that all conforming DITA content can meaningfully interoperate with all other conforming DITA content and DITA-aware processors. In particular, there is a common, invariant, mandatory base that all conforming DITA content can be understood and processed in terms of, regardless of how specialized that content is.

The specialization feature of DITA enables satisfaction of local information structuring and modeling requirements while enabling blind interchange of content and direct reuse of existing DITA-aware processing for specialized content. The DITA specialization feature enables the creation of new topic types, new map types, and new domain-specific element types for use within other map and topic types.
The DITA standard populates the DITA model with an extensible hierarchy of standard map, topic, and domain types.
